page.title: 12 HURLY HAWKINS
page.content: Close by the church of Liff, Den of Gray, are the ruins of an old castle called "Hurly Hawkin". The site is a tongue of land formed by the junction of two rivulets and the ruins form a small circular mound with large gray stones jutting out here and there. But the ruins are nearly hidden by decaying leaves and vegetation. Being of historical interest it was examined some years ago but only a spur and some ashes were found. The castle belonged to Alexander the 3rd. in the twelfth century. A house in the grounds of the old castle has been named after it.
